questions.question: Which of the following characteristic features would you expect to see in a histopathology slide of conjunctiva?

options.A: Amacrine cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
options.B: Goblet cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
options.C: Goblet cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
options.D: Amacrine cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

questions.explanation: The conjunctiva is composed of non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, which contains goblet cells that produce mucin, a key component of the tear film.

questions.question: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis?
questions.explanation: Moraxella species, a type of gram-negative diplobacilli, are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis, which is a type of chronic conjunctivitis. Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis where there is inflammation of the conjunctiva at the lid margins and the inner and outer canthi of the eyes, with red, scaly, excoriated, macerated, and fissured skin at the canthi. This is because of the proteolytic enzymes secreted by the Moraxella species. Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation, and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. These patients can also have associated blepharitis and papillary and follicular conjunctivitis. Causative organisms are Moraxella lacunata, Moraxella axenfeld, and Staphylococcus aureus (a rare cause). The source of infection is typically the nasal tract or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs. Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide, as it inhibits proteolytic enzymes. Other options: Option B: Haemophilus influenzae causes acute conjunctivitis. Option C: Adenovirus is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis and it most commonly causes follicular conjunctivitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Option D: Coxsackie B virus is known to cause aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, pericarditis, and myocarditis. There are no known mentions of ocular disease caused by the virus. Note: Pathogens that cause bacterial conjunctivitis. The below-given table elaborates on the type of conjunctivitis caused by different serotypes of adenovirus. Hyperacute (symptoms develop within 24 hours; aggressive course), Acute (resolving in less than 4 weeks), Chronic (of greater than 4 weeks' duration). Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus aureus, Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Moraxella lacunata, Haemophilus influenzae, Enteric bacteria. Conjunctivitis type: Follicular Conjunctivitis, Pharyngoconjunctival Fever, Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis. Adenovirus serotype: Adenovirus serotypes 1-11 and 19, Adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, and 7, Adenovirus serotypes 8, 19, and 37.

questions.question: A child presents with irritation and redness of the left eye at a primary health center. There are no previous immunization records. Examination showed a greyish-white membrane over the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva which bled on peeling. What is the likely etiology?
questions.explanation: The case of a child with irritation and redness of the eye with no previous vaccination records is suggestive of a case of membranous conjunctivitis, and among the given options, Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the most likely etiological agent. Membranous conjunctivitis presents with irritation and redness of the eye and is characterized by the formation of a greyish-white membrane that bleeds on peeling. Vaccines are routinely used to prevent diphtheria infection, and hence, an unvaccinated status increases susceptibility to the bacteria. Moreover, the bacteria thrive in crowded populations and poor hygienic surroundings; hence, a background of low socioeconomic context, such as an orphanage, acts as a risk factor in this case. This condition is associated with the formation of fibrinous exudates on the surface and into the substance of the conjunctival epithelium. The causes include beta-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus aegyptius, Corynebacterium diphtheria, and Neisseria gonorrhea. The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pseudomembranous conjunctivitis. It differs from membranous conjunctivitis in that the membrane can be easily peeled off in this condition, leaving an intact underlying epithelium.

questions.question: A child with pharyngitis and fever subsequently develops conjunctivitis. Initially, the left eye was affected, followed by the right eye's involvement in 2 days. Epiphora, conjunctival hyperemia, and chemosis are noted. What is its most likely etiological agent?
questions.explanation: This child with pharyngitis and subsequent involvement of the eyes most likely has pharyngoconjunctival fever. This condition is commonly caused by adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, and 7. Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute and highly infectious illness characterized by fever, pharyngitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis, and regional lymphoid hyperplasia with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. Within the classical triad, symptoms may vary in severity. It is usually bilateral, with one eye typically having onset 1-3 days prior to the second eye. It is a self-limiting disease and treatment is mainly symptomatic, as follows: cold compresses several times per day for 1-2 weeks, and artificial tears 4-8 times per day for 1-3 weeks. Newcastle conjunctivitis is usually clinically indistinguishable from this condition and is derived from contact with diseased fowls. Another conjunctivitis caused by adenovirus serotypes 8, 19, and 37 is known as epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.A: The condition is commonly associated with a benign course.
options.B: It can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension.
options.C: The blood gets absorbed gradually in 6-8 weeks time without treatment.
options.D: Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.explanation: The image given above shows a subconjunctival hemorrhage in the eye. In this condition, the blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks' time without treatment. A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension or after local trauma. The condition is commonly associated with a benign course, but if the posterior limit of the hemorrhage is not seen, one should check for a base of the skull fracture. Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia. The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.question: A UNICEF volunteer presented with a bilateral red eye of 2 days' duration beginning on a return flight from Ghana. The infection spread among all her family members within a day of her return. Initial examination revealed lid edema, serous discharge, and severe sub-conjunctival hemorrhage. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with bilateral red eye and a rapid spread of infection to family members points towards a likely diagnosis of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Examination findings of lid edema, serous discharge, and subconjunctival hemorrhage further consolidate this diagnosis. Causes: Enterovirus 70 (most important), Coxsackievirus 24, Echovirus 34, Adenovirus, Pneumococcus, Haemophilus. There is no treatment currently available. The infection generally resolves itself within a five- to seven-day period. The use of steroids can actually cause a corneal microbial superinfection, which then requires antimicrobial therapy to eliminate.

questions.question: What is the cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.explanation: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornaviruses, namely Enterovirus 70. Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, also known as 'Apollo conjunctivitis', is caused by picornaviruses such as Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A24. Rarely, it is also caused by Adenovirus type 11. It manifests with severe conjunctival congestion, chemosis, subconjunctival hemorrhages, painful follicular conjunctivitis, tearing, lid edema, and pre-auricular lymphadenopathy. The cornea may demonstrate a fine punctate keratopathy. The disease is usually self-limiting, running a course of 3-7 days. The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Enterovirus 71 (Option D) is associated with fatal meningitis, encephalitis, and paralysis. It is also implicated in Hand-Foot-Mouth disease (HFMD) and Herpangina, which is a papulo-vesiculo-ulcerative rash in the oral cavity.

questions.question: A tribal farmer, presented with a three-day history of right eye redness with pain. He had spent the prior week trekking up a mountain in order to travel to the nearby town and takes such trips frequently. The following lesion was observed on examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of right eye redness with pain, and findings of a raised whitish-yellowish lesion surrounded by mild erythema, points toward a likely diagnosis of pterygium. A history of trekking, along with chronic sunlight exposure as a farmer, acts as a risk factor because it increases the exposure to the stronger UV radiation in the mountains. Pterygium has a fatty appearance and is usually bilateral. They are more often located nasally than temporally. It has horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. They are associated with a 2- to 3-fold increased incidence of age-related macular degeneration. It is seen in most eyes by 70 years of age and in almost all by 80 years of age. Pterygium responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids. Simple excision may be warranted in rare cases, wherein pterygia may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically unsatisfactory.

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.explanation:
The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium. Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue and is never inflammatory. It occurs due to exposure to UV-B radiation, and the most common site is the nasal. It is made up of three parts: a 'cap' (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head, and a body. Clinical features: 
   • Astigmatism with the rule - most common finding
   • Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge
   • Fuchs' islets - small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge.
   The differential diagnosis is pseudo-pterygium. The treatment for pterygium is usually excision. To prevent a recurrence, mitomycin C or 5-fluorouracil is used. Other methods: 
   • Auto-grafting - Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method.
   • Bare sclera technique - high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%.
   • PERFECT surgery - zero rates of recurrence. (PERFECT stands for Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant)
   Pterygium: 
   Degenerative process
   Occurs in elderly
   Pseudo-pterygium: 
   Inflammatory process
   Can occur at any age
   Situated at the palpebral aperture
   Can occur at any site
   Either progressive, regressive, or stationary
   Always stationary
   A probe cannot be passed underneath
   A probe can be passed under the neck

questions.question: The excision of a pinkish, triangular tissue growth at the 1 o'clock position of the eye is beingperformed. The patient had a history of blurry vision and persistent redness in both eyes for amonth. In order to secure the graft in the scleral bed, which of the following will not be used?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette, with symptoms of blurry vision and persistent redness, along withfindings of an abnormal triangular mass of thickened conjunctiva, is suggestive of pterygium.Cyanoacrylate is not used for pterygium surgery.The various glues used in ophthalmology are as follows:••• Cyanoacrylate glue- Mainly used as a corneal patch to seal acute corneal perforations andimprove visual outcomes, with reduced enucleation rates and need for tectonic keratoplasty• Fibrin glue- It is a biological adhesive, which reduces the total surgical time. It is used in cornealand conjunctival surgeries, squint surgeries, cataract (to fix the haptics of intraocular lens [IOL] tothe tissue in place of sutures in glued IOL), refractive surgeries, trabeculectomy, and even retinalsurgeries.• Newer tissue adhesives like bio-dendrimers and photo-cross-linkable adhesives-105•Bovine serum albumin-based bioadhesives: used in squint surgery• Riboflavin-based bioadhesive activated on exposure to ultraviolet A: used in post-LASIK ectasia,infectious keratopathy, pseudophakic bullous keratopathy• Hyaluronic acid-based photocatalytic glue activated with argon LASER: used in the repair ofcorneal lacerations

questions.question: A man presented with red eyes associated with a sandy, gritty sensation. He was diagnosedwith conjunctivitis last week, however, his symptoms persisted. He has had multiple sexualpartners in the past. Examination revealed palpable preauricular nodes and a follicular90reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds. Conjunctival scrapings weresent for culture. What is the likely organism involved?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of red eyes, along with the examination findings of palpablepreauricular nodes and follicular reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds, issuggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis. It is also known as chlamydial conjunctivitis, caused byChlamydia trachomatis serotypes D-K. It is a sexually transmitted disease occurring commonly inyoung adults.The modes of transmission include orogenital activities and hand-to-eye spread of infective genitalsecretions. Hence, it is important to treat all sexual partners simultaneously to preventre-infection and to rule out other venereal diseases, such as gonorrhoea and syphilis. Treatmentincludes a single 1g dose of azithromycin or doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 7 days.The image given below shows the eye of a patient with chlamydial conjunctivitis.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is closely related to mucus fishing syndrome?
questions.explanation: Mucus fishing syndrome is closely related to giant papillary conjunctivitis.In Mucus fishing syndrome, patients develop a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manualremoval of mucus. The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known asgiant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC). It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear;in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC).106The increased risk in contact lens users is because of the build-up of proteinaceous deposits andcellular debris on the contact lens surface. It may be also be caused by ocular prostheses, exposedsutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.

questions.question: A young man presented with watering, redness and photophobia. He had similar complaintsin the past which improved with self-medicated topical drops. His best-corrected visual acuityis 6/36 improving to 6/24. Slit-lamp examination revealed a 3 mm × 2 mm epithelial defect inthe paracentral part of the cornea that stained positive with fluorescein dyes. What is thelikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of spring catarrh. Slit-lamp examination finding of shieldulcer is typical of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or warm weather conjunctivitis (another nameof VKC).Shield ulcers are transverse ulcers seen in the upper cornea due to epithelial macroerosionsin VKC. It is a rare complication of VKC and should always be kept in mind for patients sufferingfrom vernal conjunctivitis.Corneal signs in VKC:• Shield ulcers• Vernal plaques•Subepithelial scarring• Pseudo-gerontoxon- resembles arcus senilus; has a cupid's bow outlineTreatment of VKC is mainly with allergy avoidance and lid hygiene. Cool compresses, topicalantihistamines, topical NSAIDs and topical steroids can be used to reduce the intensity ofsymptoms.The image given below shows a shield ulcer in a patient with VKC.

questions.question: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on publichealth diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known asthe most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. Whatis the likely diagnosis?91
questions.explanation: 107The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the mostimportant cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children.Conjunctival appearance:1. In trachoma•Sago-grain appearance.• A follicular reaction2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis• Cobblestone appearance• A papillary reaction seen in palpebral conjunctiva3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis•• White-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva4. Xerophthalmia•Epithelial xerosisBitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva

questions.question: Which of the following will not be seen as a corneal sign in a 6-year-old patient withtrachoma?
questions.explanation: Arlt's line is a conjunctival sign of trachoma.CornealsignsSuperficial keratitisFollicles in the limbal areaPannus-superior limbusCorneal ulcerHerberts pits-near Limbal areaCorneal opacityConjunctivalsignsCongestion- On upper tarsal,fornix Follicles (containingLeber cellson histopathology)-On upper tarsal, fornixPapillary hyperplasia Arlt's line-Linear scarring in sulcus subtarsalisConcretions-Inspissatedmucus, dead epithelial cells in the glands of Henle

questions.question: A young girl has been brought in by her grandmother because she has constant pain,photosensitivity and discharge from her eyes. From the notes, you see that the child has hadmultiple presentations for prior eye infections. You observe severe scarring on the palpebralconjunctiva, as well as trachomatous trichiasis. Which McCallan stage will this be classifiedunder?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette of a young child with pain, photosensitivity and discharge, having repeatedinfections, along with findings of scarring and trichiasis is suggestive of trachoma. Cicatrisingtrachoma is stage 3 of trachoma and is characterized by scarring of the palpebral conjunctiva.Cicatricial trachoma is the end result of scarring that occurs in individuals who suffer from severe,persistent infections in childhood. Trachomatous scarring is recognized by the presence of easilyvisible white bands on the underside of the upper eyelid. Severe scarring can result in contractionof the tarsal conjunctiva which causes the lid margin to roll inwards. This results in buckling of108the lid so the lashes rub on the eye known as trachomatous trichiasis. These lashes can lead tocorneal opacities and scarring and eventually blindness.The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:• Stage 1: Incipient - Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.••Stage 2: Established - Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.Stage 3: Cicatrising - Scarring along with active infection.• Stage 4: Healed - Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.The image below shows trachomatous trichiasis with severe scarring-

questions.question: What is the drug of choice under the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
questions.explanation: Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma management. The adultdose is 1 g while 20 mg/kg body weight is given for children.Oral azithromycin is slowly replacing tetracycline eye ointment as the first line drug used intrachoma treatment. The experience of Morocco, the first country that used azithromycin in alarge-scale, nationwide elimination programme, has paved the way for the worldwide applicationof azithromycin as part of the SAFE strategy.

questions.question: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia. Hence, the likely diagnosis in this 21-year-old man presenting with the above lesion is xerophthalmia. Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva, which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.

questions.question: DAILYROUNDS93A 10 year old malnourished boy is brought with a 2-month history of diminished night vision.His dietary history revealed a restricted diet, consisting of mainly chips and nuggets, and hewould refuse to eat green leafy vegetables. What is the conjunctival change seen in thisdeficiency?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario indicates that this patient has nyctalopia (diminished night vision)most likely due to vitamin A deficiency, suggested by his poor consumption ofvegetables. Changes seen in the conjunctiva in vitamin A deficiency is hyperkeratosis of thesquamous epithelium.This occurs due to the metaplasia of the non-keratinized epithelium to keratinized epithelium.

questions.question: Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to irritation due to caterpillar hair. It is often mistaken for tuberculosis. On examination, small, semitranslucent, reddish and yellowish-grey nodules are formed in the conjunctiva, cornea, and iris. Microscopy contains caterpillar hair surrounded by giant cells and lymphocytes. Treatment includes excision of the nodules in the conjunctiva. The image below shows a patient's eye infected with ophthalmia nodosa.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman with redness and photophobia of the left eye was seen in the OPD. Animage of a characteristic lesion of her eye is as shown below. Identify the lesion.
questions.explanation: The given image shows a white-pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on the bulbarconjunctiva near the limbus with associated symptoms of redness and photophobia most likelyhas phlyctenular conjunctivitis. The given finding is referred to as a phlycten.Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens likeStaphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.110It is characterized by the following:• Phlycten that may eventually form ring ulcers• Shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten known as scrofulous ulcer•Fascicular ulcer with a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels that heals leaving aband-shaped opacityTreatment: Topical steroids; atropine if the cornea is involved.Note: This can be differentiated from pinguecula by the following points:Pinguecula is a yellow triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually remains freefrom conjunctival congestion. The following image shows a yellow patch with tortuous bloodvessels. There is no congestion as seen with a phlycten.

questions.question: Which of the following should not be considered in the differential of a patient who presents with the following finding?
questions.explanation: The given image shows symblepharon, which is not seen in phlyctenular conjunctivitis. It is a partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid to the bulbar conjunctiva of the eyeball. Causes of symblepharon: • Chemical injuries (especially alkalis) • Burns • Ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP) • Stevens-Johnson syndrome • Erythema multiforme • Pemphigus bullosa • Membranous conjunctivitis. Management: • Lubrication • Sweeping of fornices • Symblepharon ring • Symblepharon release and amniotic membrane graft

questions.question: What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?
questions.explanation: Chlamydia is at present the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatarum in developedcountries.Ophthalmia neonatarum also called neonatal conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctivaoccurring in an infant <30 days after birth. It should be ruled out in any infant having dischargeor watering within the first week of birth.Causes include:•Chlamydia (Option A): neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by serotypes D-K is at present themost common cause in developed countries..• Gonorrhoea(Option B): effective prophylaxis against gonococcal infection and its subsequentdecline has almost eliminated it's incidence in developed countries.• Staphylococcus aureus (Option D), Haemophilus species, Streptococcus haemolyticus, andStreptococcus pneumoniae are other less commonly seen causes of ophthalmia neonatarum•Herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatrum rarely occurs and is caused by Herpes simplex type 2virus from the mother.• Chemical conjunctivitis (Option C) is caused by the application of prophylactic antibiotics orsilver nitrate at the time of birth.Time of presentatioCausative agentnWithin 48 hChemical, Gonorrhoea48-72 hStaphylococcus aureus,Streptococcus pneumoniae5-7 days>1 weekHerpes simplex IIChlamydiaProphylactic treatment: 1% tetracycline or erythromycin eye ointment is applied to the eyes, if themother is suspected to have gonococcal or chlamydia infection.Curative treatment:• Chlamydia trachomatis (D– K)- Erythromycin eye ointment•Neisseria gonorrhoeae- Ceftriaxone injection, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment112The below image shows an infant presenting with ophthalmia neonatarum.

questions.question: An 8-year-old boy had to miss school because the matting of his eyelids made it difficult toopen them in the morning and caused severe pain. His agonized mother rushed him to thehospital and reported that he had a fever and red eye for 4 days. Which group of lymph nodesis likely to be enlarged?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of fever and red eyes, associated with matting of eyelids and pain, issuggestive of conjunctivitis. Lymph from the conjunctiva drains directly into the submandibularand preauricular nodes and hence, these group of lymph nodes are likely to be enlarged.The lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva is as follows-• From the medial side, one-third of the superior and medial two-thirds of the inferior conjunctiva→ Submandibular nodes• From the lateral side, two-thirds of the superior conjunctiva and lateral one-third of the inferiorconjunctiva → Preauricular nodesSpecialized collections of T and B lymphocytes underlying a modified epithelium is known asconjunctiva-associated lymphoid tissue (CALT) present in the stroma (substantia propria). It iscritical in the initiation and regulation of ocular-surface immune responses.Note:The stroma also consists of the accessory lacrimal glands of Krause and Wolfring whichare exocrine glands responsible for the basal secretion of the middle aqueous layer of the tearfilm.The image given below shows the lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva.113Lymphatic drainage of conjunctivaTemporalPPreauricular-Sub-mandibularOMARROWNasalW

questions.question: The image of the eye of a 32-year-old woman having superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis is given below. Which of the following is commonly associated with it?
questions.explanation: Superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis has a definite association with thyroid dysfunction. It affects one or both eyes of middle-aged women, and about 65% of patients have abnormal thyroid function (usually hyperthyroidism). It is a chronic disease of the superior limbus and the superior bulbar and the tarsal conjunctiva. Clinical features: • Papillary hypertrophy of the superior tarsal plate, often having a diffuse velvety appearance. • Hyperemia of a radial band of the superior bulbar conjunctiva that stains with rose bengal. • Superior filamentary keratitis that develops in about one-third of cases. Management: • Preservative-free lubricants • Topical acetylcysteine 10% to 20%, four times daily to break down filaments • Topical rebamipide

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not characteristic of pterygium?96

options.A: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue.
options.B: Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen.
options.C: Destruction of Bowman's layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea.
options.D: Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur.

questions.explanation: Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the conjunctival connective tissue occurs in pinguecula(and not pterygium).In pterygium, there is elastotic degeneration of collagen with fibrovascular proliferation.It is important to distinguish a pterygium from a pinguecula. A pterygium, while histologicallysimilar to a pinguecula, is distinguished by fibrovascular tissue that grows onto the cornea.114Pingueculae do not have vascularized tissue and do not cross the limbus.

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. Onexamination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the likelydiagnosis?

options.B: Vernal keratoconjunctivitisPhlyctenular conjunctivitisd) XerophthalmiaQuestion 28:Your professor has assigned you to proofread a seminar on the anatomy of the conjunctivamade by a junior. In the explanation of conjunctival follicles, you spot a wrong statement thatneeds revision. What is that statement?a) Conjunctiva of new born does not produce follicles before 2-3 months of age.b) Slit lamp may be necessary to differentiate between follicles and papillae.
options.C: Follicles are a hyperplasia of the normal vascular system.97
options.D: Follicles are found in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva.

questions.explanation: The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebralconjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.Vernal conjunctivitis is also called spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis. It primarilyaffects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years. It is primarily a type 1hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.Classical features of the conjunctiva in VKC:Palpebral VKC - Cobblestone papillae are present in the upper tarsal conjunctiva associated withropy discharge. Maxwell-Lyon sign is present which is a pseudomembrane formation of the upperlid when everted and exposed to heatLimbal VKC - Horner - Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debrisin the limbal area.The image given below shows Horner-Trantas spots.DAILYROUNDSTreatment of this condition is with topical steroids and mast cell stabilizers such as cromolynsodium. Topical cyclosporine can be used in patients who do not respond to first line treatmentmodalities.

questions.question: In the grading of trachoma, the follicular stage is defined by the presence of which of thefollowing?

options.A: 5 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva
options.B: 3 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
options.C: 5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
options.D: 3 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva

questions.explanation: In the grading of trachoma, follicular stage is defined by the presence of 5 or more follicles in theupper tarsal conjunctiva.Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide. It is caused by an obligateintracellular bacterium called Chlamydia trachomatis Serotypes A-C. The infection is transmittedby direct or indirect transfer of eye and nose discharges of infected people, particularly youngchildren who harbour the principal reservoir of infection.116The image below shows the follicular stage of trachoma -1178
